title: 107_hr2252
content: The Act titled "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases penalties for violations of conduit contribution ban. The Act "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases civil money penalties for knowing and willful violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Penalties are now not less than 300 percent of the amount involved in the violation and not more than the greater of $50,000 or 1000 percent of the amount involved. The Act "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases civil money penalties for violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Penalties are now not less than 300 percent of the amount involved in the violation and not more than the greater of $50,000 or 1000 percent of the amount involved. Additionally, criminal penalties are increased for violations involving an amount aggregating $1,000 or more. The Act "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases penalties for violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Any person who knowingly commits a violation involving $1,000 or more shall be fined or imprisoned for up to 2 years. The fine will be at least 300 percent of the amount involved, not exceeding $50,000 or 1000 percent of the violation amount. The United States Sentencing Commission will establish guidelines for these penalties. The United States Sentencing Commission will create guidelines for penalties related to violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, considering the amount involved. They will also submit an explanation of these guidelines to Congress. The United States Sentencing Commission will consider variations in contribution amounts when creating guidelines for penalties related to violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The United States Sentencing Commission will promulgate guidelines for penalties related to violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The Commission will follow the procedures outlined in the Sentencing Reform Act of 1987. The Reform Act of 1987 extends the authority under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Amendments are made to various sections of the Act, including mandatory referral to the Attorney General for violations of section 320 and changes to the statute of limitations. The Reform Act of 1987 extends the authority under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, amending the statute of limitations to 5 years for violations of section 320. These amendments apply to violations occurring after the enactment of the Act. The Reform Act of 1987 extends the ban on foreign contributions to all campaign-related disbursements. The Reform Act of 1987 expands the prohibition on foreign contributions to include all campaign-related disbursements, such as those to political committees and for independent expenditures. The Reform Act of 1987 prohibits foreign contributions for campaign-related disbursements, including those to political committees and independent expenditures. The amendments made by this section apply to disbursements made after the enactment of this Act.
